ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 3-5 hours per week
7 hours on average
3 to 7

2 hours of week not including the hours put into the final project, which we worked on throughout the entire semester. Make sure to set aside approximately 3 hours/week for the final project, or at least ~40 hours in total for this project.
2 hrs initially, then 4 hrs/week when preparing for the review

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: It could be improved by going over a specific example of how to enter studies into RevMan. Also, going more into detail about the statistics of combined estimates would be nice as its confusing when you write the review but there is no lecture or resources as to which method to use.
Excellent course, Dr. Bracken teaches and challenges students

Only take this course if you are interested in evidence supporting health practices that involve randomized control trials - good for CDE/EHS/EMD, not great for SBS& poliy. Helpful for systematic reviews (if you are prepared to teach yourself), but sitting through class itself is an absolute bore.
Excellent concepts and caring instructor. Small class size with room to discuss ideas. Material relatively up to date.Organizationally seems to be starting to fray at the edges.

A great course overall. Could be improved by adding a lecture by a librarian to on electronic search strategies for a systematic review. Having some intermediate deadlines for the systematic review would be helpful. A useful exercise might be for students to review and comment on one anothers protocols and full reviews before they are due to the professor.The assigned textbook was incredibly boring and Revman was a little difficult to use.

It might be helpful to have at least one individual meeting with Professor Bracken during the course of the semester to review and discuss the final project.The class format of one lecture and one discussion per week is helpful, especially with a small class size. However, it might be more feasible to have only one assignment per week for the discussion, with a few readings assigned for the lecture, rather than two separate assignments to prepare to discuss each week.
It was a great course. But the the review took so much time. I would be great if we had time to prepare the review during the semester instead of preparing for Thursday discussions.
A lot of work, but focused on practical and applicable skills for public health researchers

Learning how to do a thorough and proper systematic review is a great skill to have under your belt. The lectures were very insightful. However, it would have been helpful to turn some of the discussion sessions on Thursdays into lab sessions where we learn how to use RevMan.

This course is essential for clinicians like me, who want to teach and practice evidence based medicine.It is essential for research people who want to design solid studiesIt is essential for any medical person who reads medical literature

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Michael Bracken  Excellent. Very knowledgeable and approachable and interested in students' projects and understanding of the material. Some of the lectures could be updated
Instructor: Michael Bracken  Intelligent in his field, difficult to listen to as a professor

Instructor: Michael Bracken  Excellent instructor with great knowledge base. He knew a bit or more about every topic that we expressed interest in. Very impressive.One area to suggest would be to hold us more accountable for our work. Not by penalizing or treating us like children instead by truly challenging our grasp of the concepts.
Instructor: Michael Bracken  A great instructor! I enjoyed his anecdotes.

Instructor: Michael Bracken  Professor Bracken is an expert in a field of evidence-based health and a valuable resource when preparing and writing a systematic review (the final project), especially if a student plans to continue work on the project for a thesis project or publication after the end of the class.
Instructor: Michael Bracken  perfect
Instructor: Michael Bracken
Instructor: Michael Bracken  - Articulate and engaging lecturer- Very quick to respond to inquiries outside of class
Instructor: Michael Bracken  Dr. Bracken is an excellent lecturer and it is evident that he is very knowledgeable in doing systematic reviews.
Instructor: Michael Bracken  Extremely knowledgeable, a wealth of information, and stylistically exceptionalI wish the class were more interactive

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Provides and intro into how to write a systematic review and meta-analysis. However, you actually learn how to write these by doing them rather than by going to class.

Take this class- Dr. Bracken is excellent, you'll produce a publishable paper, and learn tools to do systematic reviews/meta analyses for your career. A lot of work though, both in terms of the paper and each week when he grills you during the discussion section
Would only take this if you are prepared to look at randomized control trials as the sole evidence for informing medical/public health practice.
Overall interesting course on Systematic Review. Not convinced that it requires biweekly meetings. Extremely knowledgeable instructor.
It's best to take this course if you already have in mind a topic for a systematic review.

This class helped to solidify and put into context concepts from Epi I& 2. It requires a lot of time and effort, but is a valuable experience. Prospective students should be aware that the final project, which is the bulk of the grade for the course, is a systematic review, which can be a long and complex process. This class would be especially helpful for those who already have ideas for focused research questions in their areas of interest that they would like to explore further.
A how-to course focused on the evaluation of public health/medical publications and the implementation of systematic reviews and meta-analyses
I think everybody should take this course, reviews are ubiquitous in medical work and critical appraisal of literature sould be an ubiquitous skill.
